revision.text:
'''Gabriel Villa''' (born 1965, El Paso, Texas, USA<ref>[https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/item/show/2208781081_the_art_of_gabriel_villa The art of Gabriel Villa.] - Item Details - Chicago Public Library</ref><ref>[http://www.gabrielvilla.net/pdf/border.pdf The Border of Gabriel Villa], The Art of Gabriel Villa</ref>) is a [[Lower West Side, Chicago|Pilsen]], [[Chicago]]-based artist and [[muralist]]. His influences have been "Family, U.S Texas/Mexico Border Culture, American Sports, [[1960’s Counter Culture]], [[1980’s Reaganomics]], Indigenous and Western Art".<ref>http://neotericart.com/2012/02/01/interview-with-gabriel-villa/</ref>
==2009 mural censorship controversy== In May 2009, he was commissioned to paint a mural on a [[private property]] in Chicago's Bridgeport neighborhood depicting three [[Chicago Police Department]] public [[surveillance]] cameras that carried the CPD logo along with other images, like a crucified [[Christ]], a deer head and a [[skull]]. The mural was painted over completely by the [[Graffiti Blasters]]<ref>http://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/Chicago-Graffiti-Task-Force-Paints-Over-Artists-Commissioned-Mural-Gabriel-Villa.html</ref><ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/05/16/alderman-orders-mural-wit_n_204078.html</ref> at the behest of [[11th ward, Chicago|11th ward]] [[Alderman]] [[James Balcer]], who said about the mural "My main concern is the safety and well-being for the people in this community. We have gang violence and children getting shot, and I believed that the mural sent the wrong message.”<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.gazettechicago.com/index/2009/07/balcer-orders-city-to-paint-over-mural-on-private-property/|title = Balcer orders City to paint over mural on private property|date = July 3, 2009|accessdate = April 4, 2015|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The incident sparked a local controversy over censorship, surveillance and private property.<ref>[https://sbenine.wordpress.com/2009/05/15/gabriel-villas-mural-destroyed/ Gabriel Villa’s Mural Destroyed], 05.15.2009, By Shannon Benine, mediating the medium</ref><ref>BLUECANVAS Magazine, No. 5 page 92 'Artist Vs. System' by Margarita Korol</ref>
==See also== *[[Operation Virtual Shield]]
==References== {{reflist}} ;Notes {{refbegin}} *[http://www.chicagopublicradio.org/Content.aspx?audioID=34276 Mural painted over sparks censorship debate on Chicago public radio] *[http://www.antenapilsen.com/exhibit12.html "Surveillance & Spirituality":New works by Gabriel Villa], antena
{{refend}}
==External links== *[http://gabrielvilla.net/ GabrielVilla.Net]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Villa, Gabriel}} [[Category:Censorship in the arts]] [[Category:Mass surveillance]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1965 births]]
{{US-artist-stub}}

{{Distinguish|Gauri (disambiguation){{!}}Gauri|Gawri|Gawari}} {{Multiple issues|{{POV|date=January 2018}}{{tone|date=January 2018}}}} [[File:Gavari_Bhanjara_scene_with_gypsy_trader_being_blocked_by_Meena_bandits.jpg|Gypsy trader being blocked by Meena bandits|right|260px]] '''Gavari''' is a 40-day ecstatic dance drama tradition dedicated to the [[Shakti]] [[avatar]] ''Gavari'' (aka ''Gavri'' or ''Gauri''), the principal deity of [[Mewar|Mewar's]] [[Bhil people|Bhil tribe]] in [[Rajasthan]], India. The Mewari Bhils honor Gavari as the creative protective spirit animating all life; and they perform this ritual annually to invoke, experience and celebrate Her powers.<ref name=":11">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/58471382|title=Culture and customs of India|last=Henderson|first=Carol|date=2002|publisher=Greenwood Press|year=|isbn=0313305137|location=Westport, Conn.|pages=141|oclc=58471382}}</ref> This centuries-old ceremonial cycle employs austere discipline, [[Religious ecstasy|enraptured trance]], and wild theatrics to also convey ancient myths, historic events, tribal lore, and satiric political commentary. Among all the world’s folk performance traditions, it is quite unique, especially with respect to its epiphanous energy, scale, duration, ascetic rigour and inspirational messaging as well as its still mysterious [[provenance]] and genesis.
== The Gavari Season == [[File:Masked Gavari Budia figure from rural Jaisamand troupe.jpg|Masked Gavari Budia figure from rural Jaisamand troupe|right|thumb]] Each year, ''bhopa'' [[Shamanism|shamans]] from Mewar's Bhil communities petition the Goddess to permit their villagers to perform the Gavari ritual and to accompany them for the weeks of touring. The average wait time for her consent is about 4–5 years, and once the ritual cycle begins, she must also be successfully invoked before each daily ceremony. Only when she visibly possesses one or more troupe members can the dance dramas begin and the ritual proceed.
Each of the 25-25 participating communities forms and dispatches its own Gavari company of 20-80 members. The troupes crisscross Mewar performing more than 600 day-long village ceremonies in all. In total, Gavari troupes in total can play to over a quarter of a million people annually.
During the 40-day Gavari season, all players practice strict austerities to maintain reverent contact with the living earth and the [[Immanence|immanent spirit]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/41143548|title=Tribal dances of India|last=|first=|date=1999|publisher=Discovery Pub. House|others=Tribhuwan, Robin D., Tribhuwan, Preeti R.|year=|isbn=8171414435|location=New Delhi|pages=106|oclc=41143548}}</ref> They avoid not only sex, alcohol and meat, but also shoes, beds, bathing, and eating greens (which might harm insect life). They eat only a single meal each day during the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-fridayreview/keeping-history-alive-dramatically/article2273799.ece|title=Keeping history alive dramatically}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ethnoflorence.skynetblogs.be/mask-bhil-gavari-dance/|title=MASKINDIA BHIL GAVRI GAVARI DANCE Chhoti Undri village Rajasthan : ETHNOFLORENCE Indian and Himalayan folk and tribal arts|website=ethnoflorence.skynetblogs.be|language=fr|access-date=2017-07-16}}</ref>
In the final days, each troupe returns to its home village for a last performance and closing ceremonies. The cycle ends with an immersion rite to return the Goddess’s fertility to their waters and all night raucous celebrations.
==Dramas== [[File:Gavari Bhanjara playlet characters.jpg|Bhanjara gypsy trader boasting while wife and Budia figure shrug |Kali avatar shows magic power by spitting out red-hot coals|right|thumb]] A Gavari troupe repertoire may include 10-15 classic traditional tales and new ones are still evolving, but the overarching themes are the sacredness of the natural world, radical human equality, and the feminine nature of the divine. These values are reflected in traditional Bhil society where the environment is revered, hierarchy is abhorred, and women enjoy greater rights and status than in communities outside.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mitra|first=Aparna|date=2008-06-01|title=The status of women among the scheduled tribes in India|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1053535707001254|journal=The Journal of Socio-Economics|series=Behavioral Dimensions of the Firm Special Issue|volume=37|issue=3|pages=1202–1217|doi=10.1016/j.socec.2006.12.077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indianmirror.com/tribes/bhiltribe.html|title=Bhil tribal communities|last=|first=|date=|website=www.indianmirror.com|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-07-26}}</ref>
Among Gavari’s many mythic dramas, two of the most popular and often repeated are ''Badalya Hindawa'' (The Banyan Swing) and ''Bhilurana'' (King of the Bhils).
''Badalya Hindawa'' recounts how the Goddess re-greened the Earth after a life-erasing flood and fiercely defends it thereafter from greed, stupidity and harm. The playlet features a powerful guru who loses his disciples beneath a sacred [[banyan]] tree and demands that the local king destroy it as an illicit source of power. The unnerved king complies and has the tree cut down. The Goddess and her [[devi]] sisters are outraged at this desecration and slip into his court disguised as acrobatic dancers to exact revenge. They lure the king close with their artistry, reveal their true nature, indict him for cowardice and sacrilege, and mortally terminate his reign.
[[File:Gavari_Bhilurana_scene_showing_Queen_Victoria_leading_Brit_invasion.jpg|alt=Bhilurana scene of British invaders|right|thumb|''Bhilurana: on left the British invaders, on right Bhils preparing to resist. The green parasol marks the Empress of India, Queen Victoria; the red Goddess Kali, the Bhils’ secret power source.'']] ''Bhilurana'' is the tale of a composite leader representing five centuries of Bhil resistance to intrusions of all kinds. The play compresses and conflates the armed might of Turkic, Mughal and British invaders and depicts Goddess-inspired Bhil warriors finally driving them all away with daring ambushes, sabotage and shrewd [[guerrilla warfare|guerrilla tactics]].
Both plays end with celebration, salutations to the Goddess, and clear warnings to interlopers to never violate Nature or their sovereignty again.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Gavari - Mewar’s electrifying tribal dance-drama: An Illustrated Introduction|last=Agneya|first=Harish|publisher=Tuneer Films|year=2014|isbn=978-9352123292|location=India|pages=24}}</ref>
Gavari drama emphasis inspired [[improvisation]] over rehearsal and memorisation. The beginnings and ends of Gavari dramas are known, but how things transpire in between is highly mutable. There are no scripts and many players are illiterate farmers and labourers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/humanities/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/bhils|title=Bhils - Dictionary definition of Bhils {{!}} Encyclopedia.com|website=www.encyclopedia.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-20}}</ref> Individual plays can continue for hours, contain long soliloquies and dialogues, and are only performed by a particular troupe once on four or five years. This intuitive improvisational approach fosters great creative diversity and different villages may present the same stories in many very different ways. Players strive to perform in a receptive trance known as ''[[Bhava samadhi|bhava]]'', which resembles the fluid creative state that musicians and athletes call "flow" or "[[Flow (psychology)|the zone]]".
=== Characters ===
[[File:Gavari Budia player invoking the role's tutelary spirit.jpg|Budia player|right|thumb]]Depending on the day and the plays selected a single Gavari troupe can present dozens of different characters - goddess avatars, gods, demons, historical figures, sacred animals, corrupt officials, etc. The only constant roles, which exist outside the dramas, are the '''Budia''' figure, his twin '''Rai''' devi consorts and '''Kutkadia''', the [[master of ceremonies]].
Women are not allowed to tour as actors with the troupe due to the 4-5 day [[Menstrual taboo|menstrual isolation]] Bhil women observe each month. Consequently, all female characters are portrayed by men.<ref name=":0" />
Budia embodies a powerful fusion of Shaivite and demonic energies and is a vital protective Gavari figure. He is distinguished by his dramatic horse hair-fringed mask, sacred staff and twin Rai consorts. In each day’s Gavari ceremony the Budia character has three main duties: circling the arena during opening invocations in the opposite direction as the dancers to seal in and protect the energy field they are generating; patrolling the arena perimeter during dance drama sequences to prevent audience members from entering the players' area or shaman circle unless they are clearly entranced; and periodically holding court at the arena’s edge with his Rai escorts to accept offerings on behalf of the troupe and confer blessings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gavari.info/gallery/the-many-faces-of-budia/|title=The Many Faces of Budia – Mewar Gavari|website=www.gavari.info|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-07-21}}</ref>
Every Gavari village has its own iconic Budia mask, which is treated as a sacred object and often handed down for generations.
== History ==
=== Bhils ===
{{Main|Bhil people}} One of India’s oldest and largest tribes, the [[Bhil people]] have primarily lived in the belt extending across contemporary [[Gujarat]], [[Rajasthan]], and [[Madhya Pradesh]] for at least 4,000 years. About 10 million Bhils live in India today, but only the ±7% who reside in [[Mewar]] participate in the Gavari tradition.
=== Origin === There are many speculative theories about Gavari's genesis, but its true age and origin are unknown.
According to one hypothesis, it may have begun in rural Mewar at the end of the 16th century, when Mewaris largely regained control of their lands and lives from the Mughals in [[Battle of Haldighati#Aftermath|1579]],<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/469652456|title=Medieval India : from Sultanat to the Mughals|last=...|first=Chandra, Satish, 1922-|date=2005|publisher=Har-Anand Publications|year=|isbn=8124110662|edition=Revised|location=New Delhi|pages=121–122|oclc=469652456}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/airavat/mughal-mewarconflict|title=mughal-mewarconflict - airavat|website=sites.google.com|access-date=2017-07-25}}</ref> the Rajput court gratefully awarded their mountain-dwelling Bhil brethren both unprecedented recognition and vast tracts of fertile agricultural land. The latter boon gradually drew most Bhils out of their forest encampments and began their transition to village agriculture. The 16th century hypothesis thus holds that this settling down of a semi-nomadic people created a nostalgia for their more adventurous heritage. Others assert that Gavari began in the 3rd or 4th century in Gujarat,<ref name=":8" /> and still others that it as old as Bhil culture itself and dates back four millennia.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.in/books/about/Rajasthan_State_Gazetteer_History_and_cu.html?id=ngZWAAAAYAAJ&redir_esc=y|title=Rajasthan State Gazetteer: History and culture|last=|first=|date=1995|publisher=Directorate, District Gazetteers, Government of Rajasthan|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=199, 205|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/50712988|title=Fairs and festivals of Indian tribes|last=|first=|date=2003|publisher=Discovery Pub. House|others=Tribhuwan, Robin D.|year=|isbn=8171416403|location=New Delhi|pages=57|oclc=50712988}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=http://www.udaipurblog.com/gavari-a-dance-drama-of-bhils.html|title=Gavari – A Dance Drama of Bhils|work=UdaipurBlog|access-date=2017-07-16|language=en}}</ref>
==Religious and shamanic aspects== === Invocations === [[File:Gavari ritual invocation gear.jpg|right|thumb|Ritual implements for invocation rites]] Gavari troupes perform two distinct invocation rituals. The first is used to ask the Goddess to permit a village to perform the Gavari cycle. This invocation is held in every Mewari Bhil community on or shortly before the full moon in the Hindu month of ''[[Shravana]]'', which usually falls in August as the monsoon planting season ends.
The second is to confirm Her presence and participation at the start of each day's performance. Both invocations require [[Incense in India|incense]], flowers. [[chant]]ing, [[Madal|''madal'' drum]] and ''thali'' cymbal music, a [[Shaivism|Shaivite]] [[trishula]], and the kindling of a ''[[dhuni]] fire''.
Initial sanction invocations are usually held in a darkened sanctuary attended by a small group of ''bhopa'' shamans, village elders and veteran Gavari players. Other villagers gather outside to await Her decision which is delivered by a possessed trembling ''bhopa''.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=phRzAGYR9swC&pg=PA161&lpg=PA161&dq=bhils+trance+invocatons&source=bl&ots=Lfm8IUce62&sig=GflvrHHPlRD5qRsjax96avnf7HY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjMgMLayq7VAhUmR48KHWbKDuQQ6AEILjAC#v=onepage&q=bhils%20trance%20invocatons&f=false|title=Encyclopaedia of Sociology of Religion: Sociology of religions in India|last=Nayar|first=V. G.|last2=Nayar|first2=M. G.|date=2000|publisher=Cosmo Publications|year=|isbn=9788170209751|location=|pages=161|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":10">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/609982250|title=Tribal culture, continuity, and change : a study of Bhils in Rajasthan|last=1973-|first=Majhi, Anita Srivastava,|date=2010|publisher=Mittal Publications|year=|isbn=8183242987|location=New Delhi|pages=63|oclc=609982250}}</ref> He proceeds to channel Her spirit as She explains why She will or won't allow them to perform this year. Typical reasons for refusal include discord in the village, shrine disrepair, a poor monsoon, a crop blight, etc., which must be dealt with satisfactorily before petitioning Her again.<ref name=":62">{{Cite web|url=http://www.gavari.info/gavari-introduction/|title=Gavari Introduction – Mewar Gavari|website=www.gavari.info|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-07-17}}</ref>
Daily confirmation invocations are performed around an altar in the centre of the Gavari arena where shamans, musicians and senior players gather in a tight circle. The rest of the players and occasionally villagers dance counterclockwise around this core to create a welcoming energy field. A guardian Budia figure circles the dancers in the opposite direction to seal in their energy and protect it from misuse. The Goddess spirit's arrival and presence is signaled by one or more ''bhopas'' falling into trembling [[Bhava samadhi|''bhava'' trance]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://udaipurtimes.com/gavri-the-opera-of-mewar/|title=‘Gavri’ the Opera of Mewar|date=2010-09-28|work=UdaipurTimes.com|access-date=2017-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Other requisite ritual instruments used after Her manifestation include peacock feather [[sceptre]]s to dramatize and distribute possession's quivering energetic power, and heavy ''saankal'' chains with which trance-elated participants often beat their backs.
===Possession and Trance=== Successful invocations have several visible effects. First they connect the village shaman(s) to the Goddess spirit so they can audibly articuiate Her concerns, requests and will.<ref name=":11" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=hqwYDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT77&lpg=PT77&dq=bhils+trance+invocatons&source=bl&ots=xVyok1tXBk&sig=Pv_mXXmCO_9yS2FyLPXdy1HBJyw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjMgMLayq7VAhUmR48KHWbKDuQQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=bhils%20trance%20invocations&f=false|title=Disappearing Peoples?: Indigenous Groups and Ethnic Minorities in South and Central Asia|last=Brower|first=Barbara|last2=Johnston|first2=Barbara Rose|date=2016-09-17|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781315430393|language=en}}</ref> Second, they infuse the Gavari players with creative inspiration to ably enact their roles. Finally, they can overwhelm some villagers with a sense of wonder, grace and bliss. Entranced villagers may be welcomed into the shaman circle or approached for healings and blessings by other members of the crowd. Those possessed often later report feelings of great exhilaration and selfless unity with all surrounding life. Such experiences reinforce Bhils' belief in Gavari's power, their own inalienable equality, and the sacredness of the natural world.
== Social and Cultural Significance ==
[[File:Gavari_comedic_playlet_satirizing_urban_traders.jpg|alt=Greedy urban traders|right|thumb|Satiric skit mocking fat traders who come to fleece the villagers]] In Gavari, the beauty and power of the natural world are the ultimate expression of divinity. Wilful or heedless damage to its diversity, health or future is thus regarded as not only short-sighted and suicidal, but also criminal and blasphemous.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://gavari.info|title=Mewar Gavari – Mewar's ecstatic tribal folk opera|website=gavari.info|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-07-14}}</ref> Such views are the seed [[Seven generation sustainability]] among many indigenous tribes and their current widespread battles to safeguard water resources, endangered ecosystems and [[biocultural diversity]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rabble.ca/news/2014/11/11-indigenous-resistance-movements-you-need-to-know|title=11 Indigenous resistance movements you need to know {{!}} rabble.ca|website=rabble.ca|language=en|access-date=2017-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://indiancountrymedianetwork.com/news/environment/year-of-clout-10-stories-of-indigenous-environmental-influence-in-2015/|title=Year of Clout: 10 Stories of Indigenous Environmental Influence in 2015 - Indian Country Media Network|website=indiancountrymedianetwork.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-26}}</ref>
Gavari is righteously egalitarian and disrespectful of unjust authority.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/58471382|title=Culture and customs of India|last=E.|first=Henderson, Carol|date=2002|publisher=Greenwood Press|year=|isbn=0313305137|location=Westport, Conn.|pages=156|oclc=58471382}}</ref> Its dramas vividly depict and celebrate the dispatching of powerful officials, gurus and merchants either by the mocking scorn of villagers or the sword of the Goddess in a protective maternal rage. No authority figure is spared and some playlets happily lampoon kings, Hindu gods like [[Krishna]], and even charlatan ''Bhopa'' shamans.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chandalia|first=Hemendra S I N G H|title=Tribal Dance-drama Gavari : Theatre of Subversion and Popular Faith|url=https://www.academia.edu/31877270/Tribal_Dance-drama_Gavari_Theatre_of_Subversion_and_Popular_Faith|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> The healthy skepticism such skits reflected and encouraged in [[Rajsamand district|rural Mewar]], along with other similar art forms/practices in the subcontinent helped birth India's [[Right to Information Act, 2005|2005 Right to Information Act]], which has been journalistically hailed as "the most significant change to Indian democracy since Independence" <ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1140313/jsp/opinion/story_18068459.jsp|title=The invisible history of people's movements|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2017-07-20}}</ref>
Gavari's itinerant format continues to closely network and promote solidarity among Mewar's scattered rural villages as well as their constituent castes and religious communities.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49276478|title=South Asian folklore : an encyclopedia : Afghanistan, Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka|last=|first=|date=2003|publisher=Routledge|others=Claus, Peter J., Diamond, Sarah, 1966-, Mills, Margaret Ann.|year=|isbn=0415939194|location=New York|pages=239|oclc=49276478}}</ref> Its rich mythic and historical repertoire also helps keep tribal youth aware of their heritage.<ref name=":4"/>
Gavari’s comedic skits on farm finance, greedy middlemen and corrupt merchants offer villagers wry lessons in real world commerce and economic self-defense, especially with regard to crop brokers, [[moneylender]]s, [[Usury|credit scams]], and urban conceptions of wealth.<ref name=":62"/>
Gavari tightens inter-community bonds with its month of itinerant village visitations and solidifies Bhils’ sense of responsibility for a world far beyond their neighboring fields.<ref name=":1" /> Although only Bhils play roles in the ceremony, Gavari performances also internally solidify communities by involving all castes, communities and age groups in the preparations and audience delight.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-fridayreview/keeping-history-alive-dramatically/article2273799.ece|title=Keeping history alive dramatically|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-07-14|language=en}}</ref>
== Current Status ==
[[File:Evening_Gavari_performance_at_Udaipur's_Gangaur_Ghat.jpg|alt=Evening Gavari performance at Udaipur's Gangaur Ghat|right|thumb|580x580px|"Rediscovering Gavari" program stages rare urban evening performance.at Udaipur's Gangaur Ghat.]] The Gavari tradition at home has fallen on hard times<ref name=":4" /> Rajasthan's government schools now forbid Bhil students to be [[truancy|truant]] to accompany their village Gavari troupes on their month-long pilgrimages. This alone is potentially lethal since Gavari has no scripts or schools and the only way to learn its ceremonies, arts and stories is as an [[Apprenticeship|apprentice]] participant. Add to this the accelerating exodus of working age youth to metro centers in search of employment and the average size and number of rural Gavari troupes continues decline.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/609982250|title=Tribal culture, continuity, and change : a study of Bhils in Rajasthan|last=1973-|first=Majhi, Anita Srivastava,|date=2010|publisher=Mittal Publications|year=|isbn=8183242987|location=New Delhi|pages=150|oclc=609982250}}</ref>
There are also positives. Local Bhil organizations are also becoming more active in promoting Gavari and its core values. The first English language introduction to Gavari is now available;<ref name=":0" /> lobbying is underway for [http://www.sangeetnatak.gov.in/sna/ich-inventory.php Sangeet Nakat Akademi] and [[UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists|UNESCO]] recognition of Gavari as a globally significant [[Intangible cultural heritage|Intangible Cultural Heritage treasure]]; an increasing number of Gavari clips are appearing on [[YouTube|Youtube]] and Japanese scholars have initiated innovative economic studies of Gavari's societal benefits<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://udaipurtimes.com/gavari-traditions-interest-japanese/|title=Creative Economy study on Mewar’s Gavari tradition by Japanese Researchers {{!}} UdaipurTimes.com|date=2016-09-19|work=UdaipurTimes.com|access-date=2017-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Udaipur's [[West Zone Cultural Centre]] has started presenting films and samples of Gavari artistry;<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.creanara.com/reviews/events/aarnya-parva-enthralls-audiences|title=Aarnya Parva Enthralls Audiences - Event Review @ Creanara|website=www.creanara.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-18}}</ref> and local eco-festivals are also introducing the tradition to urban audiences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://udaipurtimes.com/shakti-sunday-resonates-with-world-music-day-honors-gavari-tradition/|title=Shakti Sunday resonates with World Music Day & honors Gavari tradition {{!}} UdaipurTimes.com|date=2014-06-23|work=UdaipurTimes.com|access-date=2017-07-17|language=en-GB}}</ref> In 2016 the [http://www.gavari.info/team_member/rohit-gupta/ Udaipur District Collector] and [[Vasundhara Raje|Rajasthan Chief Minister Vasundhara Raje]] mobilized local agencies and NGOs to create "Rediscovering Gavari",<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gavari.info/rediscovering-gavari-2016/|title=Rediscovering Gavari – 2016 – Mewar Gavari|website=www.gavari.info|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-07-16}}</ref> a multi-year program to promote "Gavari as an ancient folk art miracle... spiritually arousing, artistically surprising and historically mysterious."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyudaipur.com/administration-lay-emphasis-on-gavari-festival/|title=Administration will lay emphasis on Gavari festival. {{!}} Daily Udaipur|date=2016-08-04|work=Daily Udaipur|access-date=2017-07-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
The Rediscovering Gavari program invited 12 rural troupes to perform the ceremony on different days in iconic Udaipur settings. These unprecedented events exposed thousands of tourists and townsfolk to Gavari for the first time and sparked a rare blaze of media attention.<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/udaipur/Going-global-Mewars-tribal-folk-opera-Gavri-ready-for-international-stage/articleshow/53908600.cms|title=Going global: Mewar's tribal folk opera 'Gavari' ready for international stage - Times of India|last=|first=|date=2016-08-29|work=The Times of India|access-date=2017-07-17|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://udaipurkiran.com/mewars-ecstatic-tribal-folk-opera-gavri-seeks-global-recognition/|title=Mewar's ecstatic tribal folk opera 'Gavri' seeks global recognition {{!}} Udaipur Kiran : Latest News Headlines, Current Live Breaking News from India & World|website=udaipurkiran.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-18}}</ref> This was followed by the first Gavari presentation in Delhi at the 2016 National Tribal Carnival, which was attended by Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi|Modi]] who offered lavish praise and encouragement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://m.rajasthanpatrika.patrika.com/story/udaipur/national-tribal-festival-at-new-delhi-mewar-s-gavri-dance-2362056.html|title=National tribal festival at new delhi, mewars gavri dance|website=m.rajasthanpatrika.patrika.com|access-date=2017-07-17}}</ref>

[[Image:NAMABG-Aphaia Trojan Archer 1.JPG|thumb|Archer from the western pediment of the [[Temple of Aphaia]] on [[Aigina]]; reconstruction, color variant A; as exhibited in Athens]] [[Image:Bronze head (Glyptothek Munich 457) with and without patina Bunte Götter exhibition.jpg|thumb|Juxtaposition of the colored reconstruction and the weathered original of a bronze head in the Munich exhibition]] '''Gods in Color''' (original title in [[German language|German]]: ''Bunte Götter – Die Farbigkeit antiker Skulptur'', ''painted gods - the polychromy of ancient sculpture'') is a travelling exhibition of varying format and extent that has been shown in multiple cities worldwide. Its subject is [[Ancient Greek art#Polychromy: painting on statuary and architecture|ancient polychromy]], i.e. the original, brightly painted, appearance of ancient [[sculpture]] and architecture.
== Concept == [[File:Artemis found in Pompeii.jpg|thumb|The Greek goddess [[Artemis]]; color reconstruction of a first century AD statue found in [[Pompeii]], an imitation of Greek statues of the sixth century BC. Reconstructed using analysis of trace pigments.]] The exhibition is based on the result of research on ancient polychromy, conducted especially by the Classical archaeologist [[Vinzenz Brinkmann]] since the early 1980s, based on earlier works by Volkmar von Graeve. Working together with Raimund Wünsche, the director of the [[Glyptothek]] at [[Munich]], Brinkmann developed the concept for the exhibition, culminating in the original Munich show in 2003. It displayed copies of ancient sculpture in their reconstructed painted appearance that had been produced during his studies, as well as new reconstructions created especially for the exhibition, in conjunction with the originals or comparable ancient sculptures. Soon, it began to travel to other cities in [[Germany]] and beyond.
Since 2007, the exhibition and underlying research receive support from [[:de:Stiftung Archäologie|a foundation]] created by the government of [[Bavaria]], as well as private donations. After the original German catalogue produced for the 2003 Munich exhibition, new editions were issued for later showings, most recently for the 2010 one in Berlin. An English catalogue was published for the 2008 showing in the [[Arthur M. Sackler Museum]] at [[Harvard University]]. In 2007 the Colored Gods formed part of the exhibition ''Color of Life – Polychromy in Sculpture from Antiquity to the Present'' at the [[Getty Villa]] in [[Los Angeles]], with contributions in the respective catalogue.
